div.p:
in the holiday- time of my
beauty,

and am I now a subject for
them?

'Ask me no reason why I
love you;

for though Love use Reason
for his physician,

he admits him not for his
counsellor.

You are not young, no more
am I;

you are merry, so am I;
ha, ha!

then there's more
sympathy: you love sack,

Let it suffice thee,
Mistress Page,

--at the least, if the
love of soldier

can suffice,-- that I love
thee.
I will not say, pity me;

By me, Thine own true
knight,

For thee to fight, JOHN
FALSTAFF'

What a Herod of Jewry is
this!

One that is well-nigh
worn to pieces with age

to show himself a
young gallant!

that he dares in this
manner assay me?

Why, he hath not been
thrice in my company!
What should I say to him?

I was then frugal of my
mirth:

in the parliament for the
putting down of men.

How shall I be revenged on
him?

as sure as his guts are
made of puddings.
I was going to your house.

And, trust me, I was
coming to you.

I have to show to the
contrary.

Faith, but you do, in my
mind.
Well, I do then; yet I say

I could show you to the
contrary.

O Mistress Page, give me
some counsel!
O woman, if it were not

I could come to such
honour!

take the honour. What is
it?

dispense with trifles;
what is it?
If I would but go to hell

for an eternal moment or
so,

What? thou liest! Sir
Alice Ford!

and so thou shouldst not alter
the article of thy gentry.

We burn daylight: here,
read, read;

perceive how I might be
knighted.

I shall think the worse of
fat men,

as long as I have an eye
to make difference

and yet he would not
swear;

and well-behaved reproof
to all uncomeliness,

that I would have sworn
his disposition

would have gone to the
truth of his words;
but they do no more adhere

with so many tuns of oil
in his belly,

How shall I be revenged on
him?

I think the best way were to
entertain him with hope,

till the wicked fire of
lust

have melted him in his own
grease.

Did you ever hear the
like?

but that the name of Page
and Ford differs!

To thy great comfort in
this mystery

here's the twin-brother of
thy letter:

for, I protest, mine never
shall.

I warrant he hath a
thousand of these letters,

writ with blank space for
different names

--and these are of the
second edition:

he will print them, out of
doubt;

for he cares not what he
puts into the press,
when he would put us two.

I had rather be a
giantess,

Well, I will find you
twenty lascivious turtles

Why, this is the very
same; the very hand,

the very words. What doth
he think of us?

it makes me almost ready
to

that I am not acquainted
withal;

for, sure, unless he know
some strain in me,

he would never have
boarded me in this fury.

I'll be sure to keep him
above deck.

So will I if he come under
my hatches,

give him a show of comfort
in his suit

and lead him on with a
fine-baited delay,

till he hath pawned his
horses

to mine host of the
Garter.

to act any villany against
him,

O, that my husband saw
this letter!

it would give eternal food
to his jealousy.
and my good man with him

as I am from giving him
cause;

and that I hope is an
unmeasurable distance.

Let's consult together
against this greasy knight.
Well, I hope it be not so.

Hope is a curtal dog in
some affairs:

Why, sir, my wife is not
young.

He wooes both high and
low,

With liver burning hot.
Prevent, or go thou,

for thieves do foot by
night:

Believe it, Page; he
speaks sense.

I will be patient; I will
find out this.

I like not the humour of
lying.

He hath wronged me in some
humours:

but I have a sword which can
bite upon my necessity.

there's the short and the
long.

Adieu. I love not the humour
of bread and cheese,

and there's the humour of
it. Adieu.

here's a fellow frights
English out of his wits.

I never heard such a
drawling, affecting rogue.
If I do find it: well.

I will not believe such a
Cataian,

though the priest o' the
town

commended him for a true
man.

Whither go you, George?
Hark you.

I melancholy! I am not
melancholy.

Faith, thou hast some
crotchets in thy head. Now,

Trust me, I thought on
her:

You are come to see my
daughter Anne?
Go in with us and see:

we have an hour's talk
with you.

You heard what this knave
told me,

Yes: and you heard what
the other told me?

Do you think there is
truth in them?

in his intent towards our
wives

are a yoke of his
discarded men;

very rogues, now they be
out of service.

I like it never the better
for that.
Does he lie at the Garter?

If he should intend this
voyage towards my wife,

I would turn her loose to him;
and what he gets more of her

than sharp words, let
it lie on my head.
I do not misdoubt my wife;

A man may be too
confident:

I would have nothing lie
on my head:

there is either liquor in
his pate

How now, bully-rook!
thou'rt a gentleman.

I follow, mine host, I
follow.

Good morrow and twenty, good
Master Page!

Will you go with us? we
have sport in hand.

Sir, there is a fray to be
fought

between Sir Hugh the Welsh
priest

Good mine host o' the
Garter,

Will you go with us to
behold it?

My merry host hath had the
measuring

I hear the parson is no
jester.

Hast thou no suit against
my knight,
but I'll give you a pottle
of burnt sack to give me

recourse to him and tell
him

my name is Brook; only for
a jest.

thou shalt have egress and
regress;

hath good skill in his
rapier.

Tut, sir, I could have
told you more.

These days, you stand
upon distance,

and I know not what: 'tis
the heart,

I could have made you four
tall fellows skip like rats.

I would rather hear
them scold than fight.

Though Page be a secure
fool,

she was in his company at
Page's house;

and what they made there,
I know not.

Well, I will look further
into't:

and I have a disguise to
sound Falstaff.

I will not lend thee a
penny.

Why, then the world's mine
oyster.

Which I with sword will
open.

I will retort the sum in a
quippage.

Not a penny. I have been
content,

sir, you should lay my
countenance to pawn;

I have grated upon my good
friends

and your coach-fellow Nym;
or else you had looked

through the grate, like
a geminy of baboons.

I am damned in hell for
swearing

you were good soldiers and
tall fellows;

and when Mistress Bridget
lost the handle

of her fan, I took't upon
mine honour

thinkest thou I'll
endanger my soul gratis?

At a word, hang no more
about me,
I am no gibbet for you.

Go. A short knife and a
throng!

To your manor of
Pickt-hatch! Go.

You'll not bear a letter
for me?
it is as much as I can do

to keep the terms of my
honour precise:

under the shelter of your
honour!
You will not do it, you!

I do relent: what would
thou more of man?

Sir, here's a woman would
speak with you.

Not so, an't please your
worship.
the first hour I was born.

I do believe the swearer.
What with me?

Shall I vouchsafe your
worship a word or two?

and I'll vouchsafe thee
the hearing.

There is one Mistress
Ford, sir:

I pray, come a little
nearer this ways:

I myself dwell with master
Doctor Caius,

Well, on: Mistress Ford,
you say,--

come a little nearer this
ways.

mine own people, mine own
people.

Are they so? God bless
them

Well, Mistress Ford; what
of her?

Why, sir, she's a good
creature.

Lord Lord! your worship's
a wanton!
and all of us, I pray!

into such a canaries as
'tis wonderful.

The best courtier of them
all,

when the court lay at
Windsor,

I warrant you, coach after
coach,

gift after gift; smelling
so sweetly,

all musk, and so rushling,
I warrant you,

in silk and gold; and in
such alligant terms;

that would have won any
woman's heart;

they could never get an
eye-wink of her:

in any such sort, as they
say,
but in the way of honesty:

they could never get her
so much

as sip on a cup with the
proudest

and yet there has been
earls,

but, I warrant you, all is
one with her.
But what says she to me?

Marry, she hath received
your letter,

for the which she thanks
you

and she gives you to
notify

that her husband will be
absence

from his house between ten
and eleven.

and see the picture, she
says,

leads an ill life with
him:

she leads a very frampold
life

and let me tell you in
your ear,

she's as fartuous a civil
modest wife,

and one, that will not
miss you

and she bade me tell your
worship

that her husband is seldom
from home;

but she hopes there will
come a time.

I never knew a woman so
dote

surely I think you have
charms,

But, I pray thee, tell me
this:

has Ford's wife and Page's
wife

acquainted each other how
they love me?

they have not so
little grace, I hope:

but Mistress Page would
desire you

to send her your little
page,

her husband has a
marvellous infection

and truly Master Page is
an honest man.

leads a better life than
she does:

do what she will, say what
she will,
go to bed when she list,

for if there be a kind
woman

You must send her your
page;

he may come and go between
you both;

and in any case have a
nay-word,

that you may know one
another's mind,

old folks, you know, have
discretion,

as they say, and know the
world.

woman, commend me to them
both:

there's my purse; I am yet
thy debtor.

Boy, go along with this
woman.

This punk is one of
Cupid's carriers:

Give fire: she is my
prize,

I'll make more of thy old
body

Will they yet look after
thee?

of so much money, be now a
gainer?

so it be fairly done, no
matter.

Sir John, there's one
Master Brook

below would fain speak
with you,

have I encompassed you? go
to; via!

And you, sir! Would you
speak with me?

with so little preparation
upon you.

I desire more acquaintance
of you.

Good Sir John, I sue for
yours:

for I must let you
understand

I think myself in better
plight
for a lender than you are:

the which hath something
embolden'd me

for they say, if money go
before,

Money is a good soldier,
sir,
Troth, and I have a bag

if you will help to bear
it, Sir John,

take all, or half, for
easing me

Master Brook, I know not
how I may deserve

if you will give me the
hearing.

I shall be glad to be your
servant.

Sir, I hear you are a
scholar,
I will be brief with you,

and you have been a man
long known to me,

though I had never so good
means, as desire,

to make myself acquainted
with you.

I shall discover a thing
to you,

wherein I must very much
lay open

as you have one eye upon
my follies,

sith you yourself know how
easy

it is to be such an
offender.

There is a gentlewoman in
this town;

I have long loved her,
and,

on the wing of all
occasions.

I am sure, I have received
none;

and that hath taught me to
say this:

Have you importuned her to
such a purpose?

Of what quality was your
love, then?

so that I have lost my
edifice

To what purpose have you
unfolded this to me?
When I have told you that,

Some say, that though she
appear

here is the heart of my
purpose:

authentic in your place
and person,

Believe it, for you know
it.

of your time in exchange
of it,
as to lay an amiable siege

to the honesty of this
Ford's wife:
win her to consent to you:

if any man may, you may as
soon as any.

that I should win what you
would enjoy?

on the excellency of her
honour,
that the folly of my soul

Now, could I could come to
her

with any detection in my
hand,

from the ward of her
purity,

and a thousand other her
defences,

which now are too too
strongly

What say you to't, Sir
John?

and last, as I am a
gentleman,

Want no Mistress Ford,
Master Brook;
even as you came in to me,

her assistant or
go-between parted from me:
I say I shall be with her

the jealous rascally knave
her husband
Come you to me at night;

you shall know how I
speed.

I am blest in your
acquaintance.

yet I wrong him to call
him poor;

they say the jealous
wittolly knave
I will use her as the key

I would you knew Ford,
sir,

I will stare him out of
his wits;

I will awe him with my
cudgel:

it shall hang like a
meteor

I will predominate over
the peasant,

and thou shalt lie with
his wife.
Come to me soon at night.

and I will aggravate his
style;

and shalt know him for knave
and cuckold.
Come to me soon at night.

What a damned Epicurean
rascal is this!

My heart is ready to crack
with impatience.

Who says this is
improvident jealousy?
my wife hath sent to him;

the hour is fixed; the
match is made.

Would any man have thought
this?

See the hell of having a
false woman!

and by him that does me
this wrong.

Page is an ass, a secure
ass:

I will rather trust a
Fleming

Parson Hugh the Welshman
with my cheese,

an Irishman with my
aqua-vitae bottle,

or a thief to walk my
ambling gelding,

and what they think in
their hearts

God be praised for my
jealousy!

I will prevent this,
detect my wife,

that Sir Hugh promised to
meet.

By gar, he has save his
soul,

he has pray his Pible
well,

he is dead already, if he
be come.

he knew your worship would
kill him,

By gar, de herring is no
dead
so as I vill kill him.

I vill tell you how I vill
kill him.

one, two, tree, four, come
for?

to see thee pass thy
punto,

is he dead, my Francisco?
ha, bully!

my Galen? my heart of
elder?

ha! is he dead, bully
stale?

he is de coward Jack
priest
he is not show his face.

that me have stay six or
seven,

He is the wiser man,
master doctor:
he is a curer of souls,
and you a curer of bodies;

Is it not true, Master
Page?
though now a man of peace.

though I now be old and of
the peace,
if I see a sword out,

my finger itches to make
one.

Though we are justices and
doctors

we are the sons of women,
Master Page.

It will be found so,
Master Page.

I am come to fetch you
home.
I am sworn of the peace:

and Sir Hugh hath shown
himself

You must go with me,
master doctor.

by gar, me vill cut his
ears.

He will clapper-claw thee
tightly, bully.

That is, he will make thee
amends.

for, by gar, me vill have
it.

And I will provoke him
to't, or let him wag.

go you through the town to
Frogmore.
Sir Hugh is there, is he?
see what humour he is in;

and I will bring the
doctor

By gar, me vill kill de
priest;

for he speak for a
jack-an-ape

throw cold water on thy
choler:

go about the fields with
me
Cried I aim? said I well?

By gar, me dank you for
dat:

and I shall procure-a you
de good guest,

de lords, de gentlemen, my
patients.
For the which I will be

Come at my heels, Jack
Rugby.
